page.lettertext:
17. July
1585.
From M
r
Bodelye
fol.200r
Right honorable, having signified first my bounden duty to
yo
r
H. I am to lette yow understande, that I writte my last
letter the 28 of June, & sent it from
Hambourgh
, by one
M
r
Saunders
, from whom I doe not dout, but yo
r
H. shall receave
it. Sins the writing therof, I was at
Harbourgh
with the
Duke
whose intertenment towardes me, and affection to my service,
was in every condition to my full satisfaction. Both by speech
& by writing, I receaved that from him,
whiche I would wil-
lingly certifie,
but that I see no safetie from hens, to committ
any thinge to letters.
Departing from Harbourgh, I came to
Wolfenbeitel
the
D. of Brun
swickes
Castell,
e 6 of this moneth: from whens the D was
gone in progresse, to take possession of the contreis, that were
lately fallen to him, by the death of
D. Erricke
: and of his
counsail so many as taried behind, had intelligence of nothing
in the Electo
r
s proceeding. Wheruppon I resolved to goe after
the D. but they dissuaded me from it: for that his daily re-
mooving, did make his being uncertaine: & for certaine other
respectes. So as in the end this advise was thought best, that
I should have in writing w
t
them, Wherunto I desired to
have
e D. answear: & therew
t
signifie besides, what answear
I receaved from
e
K. of Denmarke
: w
t
suche pertinent other
pointes, as I liked best my self. This they promised presently
to convey unto the D. by a messenger of purpose: & to send
w
t
all their owne letters, for my better expedition. And having
thus written, as they desired, they gave me counsail to remain
heere at
Brunswicke
(whiche is 6 miles of) till I heard
from the D. For at Wolfenbeitel in the D. absence, no
straunger is permitted, to come w
t
in
e gates. And this their
conference w
t
me, was in
e Suburbes of
e towne.
Yesterday, the 16 of this moneth, there came unto me from Wol-
fenbeitel, one of
e Counsail, who shewed me the D. letter, in
answear to theirs: in whiche he willed them to tell me, that in
part he had receaved, an answear
from
e Electo
r
s: but he ex-
pected yet an other, to his better contentation
. And therfor he
wished me, to stay still at Brunswicke, till he came againe to
Wolfenbeitel, where he purposed to be, about
e last of this moneth.
This partie tolde me further, but as proceeding from him self,
fol.200v
that for secret causes, that he knewe, he thought the Electo
r
s reso-
lution, would be too good purpose.
I have also otherwise had
intelligence, what caused that meeting at
Netzling
in
sylva
Garlebiensi
, w
c
I writte of in my last: where
e
D. of Saxonie
&
his sonne
, the
Marchese of Brandeb
.
e
D. of Mechelb
.
and
others, about 8 daies sins assembled, but taried not longe, be-
cause Saxonie sickened. From
e place where I am, I can not
send in other sort, but by persons unknowen, w
c
maketh me
suppresse, that whiche is of some consequence, & were expedi-
ent to be written.
I have a copie of
e
last
letter (Whiche I mentioned in my last)
written from
e Electo
r
s to
e
K. of Navarra
. It is knowen heere
to very fewe, & I can not learne as yet, whether it were sent
him or no. It was dated in Marche, & is only subscribed by
the 2 Electo
r
s,
e
Administrato
r
of Magdeb
.
e
D. of Bipoint
D. Julius of Brunsw
.
D. Will
.
of Brunsw
.
D. of Mechelb
.
&
e
D. of Wirtenberg
. The effect is the same as I signi-
fied before: A request unto
e K. to subscribe the booke of Con-
corde: and all the answear is so framed, as I wonder at it
muche, for the maner that it useth. For the K. is flatly exhorted
to beware of
Beza
, & those deceavers ( for so they are termed)
w
t
many wordes & clauses so straungely sette downe, as if
e
replie therunto be correspondent unto it, it can not choose but
occasion a greater discorde then before.
Againe there is no end in these quarters of printing their In-
vectives, whiche are conceaved in suche termes, as are mer-
velous bitter and uncharitable.
Chemmicus
e chief
Pastor of Brunswicke, & one of
e greatest clarkes of that
sect, & of later time in all
Germanie
, hath lately penned
a preface to an other mans booke against
Dan
ae
us
: wherein
he exhorteth the Magistrats & Churche of
Brunswicke
, and
all others in autoritie, to banishe all Calvinists, and of their
territories, & to detest them as men, that knowe themselves
in conscience to be damned persons: calling God to witnes
that they will shortly fill Christendome w
t
the impieties of
Mahomet: w
t
other like speeches so ungodly & unconsciona-
ble, & wittingly untrue, as it is not almost credible.
This maner of writing in a principall divine, the rest doe
so imitat, & the people so regard, that this peace in religi
o
wilbe many yeres in concluding.
fol.201r
For mine owne part, I have alwaies heere amonge them, bent
all my persuasion, to procure a common concurrence against
an ennemie to both sides. And for matters of
e Churche, I
doe kepe my self silent, but that I notifie where I come, the
modestie of o
r
Ministerie, that shunne all occasions to preach
of
Luthers
opinions: & when occasion is presented, doe never
taxe him in any thing, but w
t
a reverent respect.
I was w
t
Chemmicus sins my comming to this towne, and to
tell yow howe I founde him, it would but lengthen a letter, &
too muche comber yo
r
H. But as I was w
t
him, so w
t
others
besides, w
c
are Ministers of name, but towardes us for o
r
doctrin,
ill affected like to him, w
t
whome I have conferred, and
urged strictly to the point, that notw
t
standing these conten
tati-
ons, we might drawe together in a Line, & oppose or se
...
jointly against the
Pope
& his Complices. Whereunt
o ...
bin answeared, that as the case was proposed, they thought
their brethren might be dealt w
t
all so, as they would
not only not dissuade it, but be a meanes unto their So-
veraignes, to condiscend to suche petitions. Wherby I doe
perceave, that
e maner heere of proceeding, is muche to be
respected. For if they be dealt w
t
all calmly, not tou-
ched in their doctrin, & warely solicited, no dout in short
time, they might be wonne to joine with us.
Heere in Brunswicke I am feasted, presented, and visi-
ted, muche more then I would be: by meanes wherof, &
of so many voiages too & fro, intertenments where I come, &
longe aboade in these contreis, that allowance of her
Ma
tie
w
c
was given me in prest, would serve me but a while. How
beit, I referre my self for that, to yo
r
honorable wonted favo
r
whiche I hope will afourde me those necessarie reasons, wh
...
by her Hig
nes
wilbe moved, to some gracious consideration
Wherew
t
I take my humble leave, alwaies mindfull in my
praiers, to commend yo
r
welfare in body, & happines in
Honor to Gods preservation. Brunswicke. Julij 17 158
5
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden.
Tho. Bodley
I am newly advertised that
Andreas
Pauli
is sent from
e Electo
r
s, to the D.
of Brunswicke w
t
a packet: wherein
is thought to be contened their answear
to her Ma
tie
.
